[h1] My Experience with Dead by Daylight [/h1]

This game is very unique- a fun, asymmetrical game which involves you to either outsmart and escape a ruthless killer or completely dominate and slaughter a team of four survivors. I've had many hours on both sides, I've felt the rush of being able to run and bait a killer for the whole trial and I've also felt the genuine excitement and pride that comes from being able to kill each and every survivor within just minutes of the trial starting. I've also felt the complete opposite of these scenarios, and I feel like I can be able to fully vouch for and critique some aspects of Dead by Daylight. 

[u] The Beginning: [/u]

I started playing this game in around Chapter 12, the Ghostface chapter. And immediately, I found this game severely challenging, as I has no idea what I was doing. But eventually, through the use of experience and watching content creators, I have made it decently up the ladder in ranks, achieving purple and red ranks on both killer and survivor. And one thing I can say with beyond a doubt. Is that the content creators for this game have built an amazing community, while the core game may be toxic at times (which multiplayer game isnt though?), the content creators are just so passionate and caring about this game. It isn't hard to find entertainment watching people play this game.

However, playing this game can be and will be quite frustrating, as the uniqueness of this game requires special skill specific to this game alone. The initial learning curb to be "good" or "efficient" is quite high, on both killer and survivor, I would say. Not to mention that if you are not willing to spend money for the DLCs, you will often be stuck with nothing but mediocre perks or killers. [i] The base game entertainment is horrendous and you will miss out on a lot of fun if you do not have the money to buy DLCs and perks. [/i] 

Speaking of perks, being able to actually unlock perks you bought through DLCs is a nightmare. Sure, you can always use the base perks that each different survivor comes with and build upon that, but that building part will take hours upon hours. This is especially important on killers though, as a lot of killers need different perks than just their base because they often rely on a very specific playstyle that said perks allow for. The bloodweb and bloodpoint system is extremely grindy and often feels like more of a gambling system than lootboxes are. You could easily spend 2 million bloodpoints (equating to playing anywhere between 40 to 100 matches) and still not find that one specific perk you need. When put into terms like stated, it seems absolutely absurd.

[u] The Community and The Devs [/u]

This specific topic is one I feel completely justifies my opinion for not recommending the game. Behaviour has a very, very awful track record when it comes to consistency and community awareness and response. More specifically, BHVR just does not even try and communicate with it's player-base, it seems. They often have little to no outreach when it comes to bugs, new killers, patches, community feedback, etc. Instead, they simply just pop things into existence, even if it wasn't wanted by a vast amount of the community. They simply do not care. And would rather say "well, it's already in the game so..." and we just have to deal with it.

Every single chapter, whether it be a wanted chapter or not, comes with a fresh new set of bugs, due to BHVR's negligence and awful coding system. They keep adding and adding onto whatever mess of spaghetti code they have, and something always breaks. In Chapter 19, All-Kill, this problem is no different. Basic functions and mechanics in this game like pallets and pallet interactions with the killer just do not work. You can be sure to experience that and other issues in future chapters. Big ones in the past include d-sync errors, sound (or lack thereof) errors, falling through the map, hooked survivors just full on levitating, killer powers just freezing and getting animation stuck, and many many more. These stated issues, more specifically though, happen all the time in new chapters. And it begs the question, "just what does BHVR do in the PTB?"

The simple answer is: very little. The PTB primarily only exists as a marketing strategy and makes very little impact to the full release to the game. New killers or survivors will often get their perks tweaked (either due to under-performance or completely not working), and addons for the new killer will experience the same treatment. But bugs, criticism, and feedback? Largely ignored.

[h1] In Short [/h1]

Dead by Daylight is a game that I simply cannot recommend to players seeking consistency and longevity. Watching and playing this game, I cannot help but feel that Behaviour is slowly but surely running this game into the ground. The constant lack of communication and want of feedback is hurting this game severely, and new content feels like nothing but a dry cough, a cry from BHVR, saying that they still- while very little- update the game. And as time goes on, as Dead by Daylight does indeed unlock more and more content, a newer player will drown in money in order to play the game at it's greatest potential.
